title: God, titles and names of
comment: These reflect the great and varied aspects of God's being and character. They are particularly used by the psalmists to speak of God as a source of strength, security, blessing and hope.

children.title: God, human descriptions of
children.comment: Figures of speech which describe God in human terms, sometimes referred to as anthropomorphisms. Since God is Spirit, these expressions help the human mind to understand God, and enable God to reveal himself to human beings.

primaryrefs.comment: God's arm is particularly used as a symbol of his power at the exodus.
God's hearing usually refers to his answering of prayer.
God's smelling refers to his acceptance of sacrifices.
God as a potter.

children.title: God is not to be brought down to human levels
God, feminine descriptions of
children.comment: Some expressions attribute feminine qualities to God, especially relating to motherhood.

children.title: Descriptions of God relating to childbirth
God gives birth to his people

primaryrefs.comment: God giving birth to Israel at the exodus.

children.title: Descriptions of God relating to motherhood
God as a mother bird protecting her young
God, as shepherd
children.comment: The image of God as a shepherd points to his continual direction, guidance and care for his people.

children.title: Shepherd as a title for God
The tasks undertaken by God the shepherd
The shepherd saves those who are lost or scattered
God gives shepherds to be leaders over his people
God, as Spirit
children.comment: God has no material body and he is not subject to human limitations. While his spiritual nature is clearly inferred in Scripture, it is seldom directly stated; the emphasis is on his dynamic, living personhood.

children.title: God is not subject to physical limitations

secondaryrefs.comment: Elijah's mockery of Baal implies a contrast with the true God who is not subject to the limitations suggested

seealsos.comment: The Spirit and the presence of God are equated
God's guidance and the Spirit's leading are equated
God's Spirit participates in God's plans

children.title: God, the Lord
children.comment: God is the almighty ruler to whom everything and everyone is subject. His lordship is seen in his power and his victory over his enemies and also in his deliverance of his people and his loving care for them. He is the recipient of their obedience and their prayers. (``Lord'' is the translation of the Hebrew word ``Adonai'' meaning ``Ruler'' or ``Master'' and is distinct from ``LORD'' which is the translation of the divine name ``Yahweh''.).

primaryrefs.comment: God exercises his lordship over all creation, but especially over all humanity.

children.title: He is Lord of all the earth
God, the Lord, is triumphant over his enemies
God, the Lord, delivers his people and cares for them
As a mark of respect or obedience
Jesus Christ is God, the Lord
God, the LORD
children.comment: The translation of the Hebrew name ``Yahweh'' which is the personal name of God whose meaning was revealed to Moses. It emphasises that God is the one who is eternal, unique, unchangeable and always actively present with his people. It expresses God's role as Israel's Redeemer and covenant Lord.

children.title: The name of God, the LORD
The LORD is the personal name of God

primaryrefs.comment: ``The LORD'' is the NIV rendering of the Hebrew ``Yahweh''.
This forms part of God's explanation of who he is. ``I AM'' (in Hebrew closely resembling ``Yahweh'') expresses the ever-present, unchanging, totally dependable character of God.

children.title: The name is revealed to Moses

primaryrefs.comment: The name had been used previously (e.g., Ge 4:26) but its meaning was not fully understood until God revealed it to Moses in the context of the exodus from Egypt.

children.title: The name is glorious and awesome
The name is not to be misused

primaryrefs.comment: The misuse referred to here is swearing falsely by God's name.

seealsos.comment: The Jews came to believe that just uttering the name ``Yahweh'' was an offence and as a result its exact pronunciation has been lost. What merited the death penalty here was using God's name as a curse.

children.title: God's character is revealed by his name the LORD
He is actively present with his people
God reveals the relevance of his name the LORD by his actions

seealsos.comment: ``The LORD'' is Creator of the universe but also the Creator of the people Israel
Human beings are the purpose of God's creation; they know God as ``the LORD''.

children.title: In the deliverance of his people from Egypt

primaryrefs.comment: Deliverance is a central concept in the revelation of the divine name.

children.title: In establishing a covenant with his people
In the judgment of his enemies
In the restoration of his people

seealsos.comment: The theme ``then you, my people, will know that I am the LORD'' (with slight variations) runs throughout the book of Ezekiel and is connected to divine acts of judgment and restoration.

children.title: God, the LORD denotes God's lordship

primaryrefs.comment: ``Sovereign LORD'' is the NIV rendering of ``Adonai Yahweh'', the favourite divine title in Ezekiel.
``The LORD Almighty'' is the NIV rendering of ``Yahweh Sabaoth'' (``the LORD of hosts'') which emphasises the sovereignty of ``the LORD''.

children.title: He is the Lord, the LORD Almighty

primaryrefs.comment: ``The Lord, the LORD Almighty'' is the NIV rendering of ``Adonai Yahweh Sabaoth'' which is often associated with the LORD's authority to rule and to judge.

children.title: As the LORD, God interacts with his people

primaryrefs.comment: The phrase ``I am the LORD'' occurs over 40 times in Leviticus chapters 18-26 and is the authority behind the moral law given to God's people.

children.title: He is the object of his people's worship

primaryrefs.comment: The purpose of Israel's redemption from Egypt was that they would be free to worship the LORD.

children.title: Jesus Christ takes God's name to himself

primaryrefs.comment: The form of expression used by Jesus Christ meant that he was clearly identifying himself with the divine name ``I AM''. The response of the crowd confirms this.

children.title: God, the Rock
children.comment: An OT title for God and a Messianic title signifying that God's people can rely on him for absolute protection and salvation.

children.title: Rock as a title for Israel's God
The Rock is superior to other gods
The Rock is worthy to be praised
God the Rock and his people
God the Rock is a refuge for his people
God the Rock is his people's fortress
God the Rock is his people's security
God the Rock saves and delivers his people
The Messiah is the rock/stone on which God's living temple stands
The Messiah's kingdom is eternal and immovable like a rock
God of the fathers
children.comment: God's particular association with Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, the fathers of the nations of Israel, highlights his faithfulness in fulfilling the promises made to them. He is the God who establishes a covenant with his people for their everlasting blessing.

children.title: The God of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob

primaryrefs.comment: ``Jacob'' is used here as a synonym for the nation of Israel. This usage is common in the Psalms as a reminder to God's people of his faithfulness to Jacob and the emergent nation of Israel.

children.title: Such a relationship served as an encouragement to others
children.precomment: Abraham's servant was encouraged to trust God in his mission by the example of Abraham's faith:

secondaryrefs.comment: Jacob learned to fear and trust God through his father Isaac.

children.title: God's promises that they will be the fathers of a great nation
God remembers and fulfils his promises
God makes a covenant with his people to be their God
Characteristics of the God of the fathers
He is the God of the living
People sometimes fail to respond to the God of their fathers

primaryrefs.comment: This was the special name by which God revealed himself to the patriarchs. The Hebrew is ``El-Shaddai'' possibly meaning ``God the mountain'', emphasising God's might.
The Hebrew ``El-Elyon'' denotes the supremacy and sovereignty of God.
The Hebrew ``El-Olam'' only occurs in this verse.
``the Holy One of Israel'' is a favourite divine title in the book of Isaiah.

cschildren.title: Titles which refer to God as LORD
Titles referring to God as the source of light

secondaryrefs.comment: the Father of the heavenly lights

cschildren.title: Titles referring to God as the source of strength
Titles referring to God as the source of security
Titles referring to God as the source of provision
Titles referring to God as the source of hope
Titles referring to God as the source of peace
Titles referring to God as the source of comfort
Titles referring to God as the source of grace
Titles referring to God as the source of love
